summary: A New York Times article from August 26, 2019, detailing the accounts of two sisters who made the earliest known allegations against Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell in 1996. The article describes their initial encounters, the assaults they reported, their failed attempts to alert authorities and the media, and the subsequent threats and impact on their lives.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually assaulting the sisters and other young women. The article details his pattern of luring vulnerable girls, his interactions with the sisters, and his eventual arrest and death.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's companion who played a key role in bringing young women to him, including the sisters. She is accused of participating in the assaults and later making threats.

persons.name: Maria
persons.context: One of the two sisters. An artist introduced to Epstein in 1995. She describes being violently groped by Epstein and Maxwell in Ohio in the summer of 1996 and subsequently reporting the crimes.

persons.name: Annie
persons.context: Maria's younger sister. She describes an uncomfortable trip to Epstein's New Mexico ranch in early 1996, where she received a topless massage from Maxwell. Her experience prompted Maria to report to authorities.

persons.name: Mike Baker
persons.context: Author of the New York Times article.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as someone whose potential visits caused bustle at Epstein's townhouse, though Maria never saw him there. He has acknowledged knowing Epstein.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Maria met in Epstein's office. She recalls Epstein telling Trump "she's not for you." Trump has acknowledged knowing Epstein.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Maria's lawyer, with whom she is working to support other victims of Epstein.

persons.name: Graydon Carter
persons.context: The editor who, according to the article, said the sisters' sourcing for a 2003 story did not meet the magazine's legal standards. Reporter Vicky Ward suggested he succumbed to pressure from Epstein.

persons.name: Vicky Ward
persons.context: The reporter who interviewed the sisters for a 2003 Vanity Fair article about Epstein. The article was published without their account.

persons.name: John Connolly
persons.role: Former contributing editor at Vanity Fair
persons.context: Recalled Carter talking about Epstein's efforts to influence the 2003 Vanity Fair article.

persons.name: Edgar Degas
persons.context: Mentioned as an inspiration for one of Maria's paintings.

connections.description: Described as companions who worked together to recruit young women and participated jointly in the alleged assault on Maria.
Epstein offered Maria a job, then he and Maxwell allegedly assaulted her. He is the central figure in her allegations.
Maxwell allegedly participated in assaulting Maria and later threatened her over the phone.
Epstein invited Annie to his ranch and engaged in unwanted touching. Maxwell gave her a topless massage at the ranch.
Sisters. Maria brought Annie into Epstein's orbit and later learned of Annie's troubling experience.
Acknowledged knowing each other. Clinton's potential visits caused activity at Epstein's home.
Acknowledged knowing each other. Maria met Trump in Epstein's office.
Maria is working with lawyer David Boies to support other Epstein victims.

events.title: Maria introduced to Epstein
events.description: Maria, a recent art school graduate, is introduced to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell at a gallery show by her dean.

events.title: Annie's visit to New Mexico ranch
events.description: Annie visits Epstein's New Mexico ranch, where she experiences unwanted touching from Epstein and receives a topless massage from Maxwell.

events.title: Assault on Maria in Ohio
events.description: At Epstein's Ohio estate, Epstein and Maxwell allegedly grope Maria over her clothes, comment on her features, and twist her nipples, causing bruising. She flees and barricades herself.

events.title: Sisters report to authorities
events.description: Maria reports the assault and theft of her nude photographs to the NYPD and the FBI. The NYPD refers her to the FBI due to jurisdiction (Ohio). She also contacts the art community.

events.title: Vanity Fair article interview
events.description: The sisters give a detailed interview to Vanity Fair reporter Vicky Ward for a story on Epstein. The article is published without their account, which they believe was due to pressure from Epstein.

events.title: FBI interviews sisters
events.description: FBI agents knock on Maria's door and interview both sisters as part of the Florida investigation into Epstein, renewing hope for accountability.

events.title: Epstein's plea deal
events.description: Epstein enters a widely criticized plea deal, pleading guilty to state prostitution charges and avoiding federal prosecution, which demoralizes the sisters.

events.title: Epstein's death in custody
events.description: After being arrested on federal sex trafficking charges, Epstein dies in what authorities call an apparent suicide.

locations: New York (Epstein's townhouse, NYPD precinct, West Side Highway)
keyFacts: Two sisters, Maria and Annie, made the earliest known allegations against Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell in 1996, describing assaults and recruitment.
Maria reported the 1996 assault to the NYPD and the FBI, but no significant action was taken at the time, highlighting early failures in the investigation.
The sisters attempted to tell their story to Vanity Fair in 2003, but the article was published without their account, which they attribute to pressure from Epstein.
Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly threatened Maria after the Vanity Fair interview, telling her to "be really careful because there are a lot of ways to die" on the West Side Highway.
The article reveals that Donald Trump was present in Epstein's office when Maria was there, and that Epstein told Trump "she's not for you."
